questions.question:
Question 1: A patient walks with a stomping gait. When asked to close his eyes and walk, he is unable to 
do so. Which of the following tracts is probably affected?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the involvement of the posterior column. Posterior column carries proprioception which is essential for coordination of motor movements. 
Loss of this leads to the development of a stomping gait. This is seen in cases of vitamin B12 
deficiency leading to subacute combined degeneration, tabes dorsalis or diabetic neuropathy.

questions.question:
Question 2: Which of the following features would you not expect to find in a patient with cerebellar 
ataxia?
questions.explanation:
Intention tremor is a feature of cerebellar ataxia, not resting tremor. Cerebellar ataxia is characterized by the following symptoms: 1245 
Sold by @itachibot • Gait impairment • Unclear speech or scanning speech • Blurred vision due to nystagmus • Dysdiadochokinesis • Intention tremors - tremor on goal-oriented movements Bilateral and symmetric involvement suggests the following etiologies: • Genetic - SCA gene mutations • Metabolic - Vitamin B1 or B12 deficiency • Immune - Antigliadin antibody syndrome • Toxic - Phenytoin, amiodarone, alcohol Focal, unilateral symptoms with headache, impaired level of consciousness, ipsilateral cranial 
nerve palsies and contralateral weakness suggest a space-occupying cerebellar lesion.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 70-year-old man presented with gait instability, slurring of speech, and intention tremors, 
for a few months. He was a former smoker who quit 10 years back. After extensive workup, a 
paraneoplastic cause was suspected, and chest CT was ordered. It showed a 3cm wide mass 
near the right hilum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of paraneoplastic cerebellar ataxia, which is most likely to be 
caused by small cell lung cancer here. Paraneoplastic syndromes causing cerebellar ataxia are associated with various antibodies: Sometimes, paraneoplastic ataxias may be the only presenting symptom of the underlying cancer. 
In paraneoplastic cerebellar ataxias, serum anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD) antibodies

questions.question:
Question 4: 1242 
Sold by @itachibot What is the most common inherited ataxia?
questions.explanation:
Friedreich's ataxia is the most common form of inherited ataxia (autosomal recessive), comprising 
one-half of all hereditary ataxias. Friedrich's ataxia has autosomal recessive inheritance and presents before 25 years of age. The 
median age of death is 35 years. Women have a significantly better prognosis than men. Friedrich's ataxia presents with clinical features such as dysarthria, progressive staggering gait, 
frequent falls and titubation. Other neurological symptoms include nystagmus, loss of fast 1246 
Sold by @itachibot saccadic movements, loss of vibratory and proprioceptive sensation, and ataxia or trunk and limb 
movements. The lower extremities are more severely involved than the upper ones. Cardiac involvement occurs in 90% of patients. It presents with cardiomegaly, symmetric 
hypertrophy, and conduction defects. Musculoskeletal deformities are common and include 
progressive scoliosis, pes cavus, and pes equinovarus.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 24-year-old man presents with complaints of swaying while walking, frequent falls and 
slurring of speech. He also gives a history of involuntary nodding movements of the head. On 
examination, you note the following findings. Which of the following regions of the spinal 
cord is involved first in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of Friedrich's ataxia, in which the dorsal root ganglion cells 
are involved first. The primary sites of pathology are the spinal cord, dorsal root ganglion cells, and the peripheral 
nerves. Spinal cord tracts are involved, and degeneration occurs predominantly in the spinocerebellar 
tracts, lateral corticospinal tracts, and posterior columns. Degeneration of cranial nerves 
(glossopharyngeal, vagus, hypoglossal) and deep cerebellar nuclei can occur. Peripheral nerves are 
also involved, and there's a loss of large myelinated fibers. Cerebellar atrophy is also seen. Cardiac changes occur due to myocyte hypertrophy, fibrosis, and degeneration of cardiac ganglia. Note: Friedrich's ataxia may also be associated with vitamin E deficiency.

questions.question:
Question 6: A middle-aged vegan woman presented with tingling and numbness over the limbs and 
progressive fatigue. Her peripheral smear is given below. Which of the following neurological 
manifestation would you not expect to see in this condition? 1243 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario and smear showing macroovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils, is 
suggestive of megaloblastic anemia caused by vitamin B12 deficiency. Myopathy is not a feature of 
vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 deficiency may produce the following neurological manifestations: • Loss of vibration sense and proprioception • Paresthesia - upper limb paresthesias occur before lower limbs are affected. • Unsteady gait - due to sensory ataxia • Peripheral neuropathy • Optic neuropathy • Psychiatric manifestations such as: • Irritated behavior • Severe dementia • Frank psychosis

questions.question:
Question 7: A 30-year-old man presented with swaying while walking, tingling in palms and feet, and 
blurring of vision. On examination, deep tendon reflexes are absent, proprioception and 
vibration sense are absent over the lower limbs. MRI spine reveals diffuse demyelination. 
What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
1247 
Sold by @itachibot The given case scenario is suggestive of subacute combined degeneration (SACD) due to vitamin 
B12 deficiency. SACD presents with the following features: • Loss of vibration sense and proprioception • Paresthesia - upper limb paresthesias occur before lower limbs are affected. • Unsteady gait - due to sensory ataxia • Loss of deep tendon reflexes • Peripheral neuropathy • Optic neuropathy - can present as blurring of vision • Psychiatric manifestations such as: • Irritated behavior • Severe dementia • Frank psychosis MRI spine shows myelopathy and areas of demyelination. Myelopathy of SACD tends to be diffuse 
rather than focal. Treatment is replacement therapy is with 1000 g of intramuscular vitamin B12 repeated at 
regular intervals or by oral vitamin B12.

questions.question:
Question 8: The investigations of a male truck driver are given below. Which of the following is he 
unlikely to present with?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of tabes dorsalis. It presents with loss of reflexes in lower 
limbs, not hyperreflexia. Tabes dorsalis (or syphilitic myelopathy) is a slow degeneration and demyelination of the neural 
tracts. It is seen in tertiary syphilis. It primarily involves the dorsal columns of the spinal cord and 
dorsal roots. It presents with the following clinical features: • Loss of reflexes in lower limbs • Romberg's sign • Bilateral Argyll Robertson pupils - accommodation reflex present, pupillary reflex absent • Loss of position sense and vibration • Stabbing/pricking pain in the legs - this is fleeting or repetitive • Ataxia of the legs and gait disturbances • Paresthesias • Bladder disturbances • Acute abdominal pain with vomiting - visceral crisis Note: Diabetic polyradiculopathy may simulate tabes. 1248 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is false regarding ataxia telangiectasia?

options.a: Presents in 4th to 5th decade of life.
options.d: Increased incidence of lymphomas is seen

questions.explanation:
Ataxia-telangiectasia is an autosomal recessive condition presenting in the first decade of life. It is associated with a high incidence of recurrent pulmonary infections, lymphomas, Hodgkin's 
disease, breast cancer, and acute T cell leukemias. Histology shows loss of Purkinje cells, granules, and basket cells in the cerebellar cortex. There is 
a loss of neurons in the deep cerebellar nuclei, inferior olives of the medulla, and anterior horn 
and dorsal root of the spinal cord. Clinical features of ataxia-telangiectasia include: • Progressive telangiectatic lesions • Oculomotor apraxia • Truncal and limb ataxia • Dysarthria • Extensor plantar reflexes • Myoclonic jerks • Areflexia • Distal sensory deficits • Nystagmus • Cellular and humoral immunodeficiency (absent/ill-developed thymus)

questions.question:
Question 10: 1244 
Sold by @itachibot An elderly woman is brought to the OPD with complaints of behavioral change, a history of 
multiple falls, urinary incontinence, and dementia. What is your diagnosis?

options.c: Schwann cell–derived myelin sheath covering the beginning of the nerve
options.d: Schwann cell–derived myelin sheath covering the terminal part of the nerve

questions.explanation:
The given case scenario describes an elderly woman with urinary incontinence, dementia 
(cognitive decline), and a history of multiple falls (suggestive of a gait abnormality or ataxia). 
These form the classical triad of normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). Both frontotemporal dementia (Option B) and Parkinson’s disease (Option C) are common causes 
of dementia associated with falls, but urinary incontinence is not commonly appreciated. NPH is, 
therefore, the most likely diagnosis. Normal pressure hydrocephalus refers to a disproportionate enlargement of the ventricles 
compared to the degree of cortical atrophy. It is a communicating hydrocephalus caused by 
delayed resorption of cerebrospinal fluid. Out of the classical triad of symptoms, most patients 
present with one or two. Hence, neuroimaging showing dilated ventricles is essential, as well as an 
L- dopa challenge test to rule out parkinson’s disease is recommended. A characteristic MRI of NPH is given below, showing dilated lateral ventricles which are out of 
proportion to sulcal deepening: 1249
